subject: RE: Simplifying testing (was OT? (Re: [junit] Testing initial conditions))
msgSnippet: Very well stated! And I would say not off-topic at all, if you take the view (as I think that we both do) that testing can also be done by eliminating things
messageBody:
Very well stated! And I would say not off-topic at all, if you take the
view (as I think that we both do) that testing can also be done by
eliminating things that need testing.

By eliminating sequence dependencies from your API, you have eliminated
a test condition and thereby made it easier to verify your object and
it's API. Anything that is made simpler has a by-product of being less
likely to break.

Also: JavaBeans can be used for good rather than evil. I only use them
as data-holders, and use "real" objects for the heavy lifting! :-)

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
>Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:09 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: OT? (Re: [junit] Testing initial conditions)
>
>
>The "Samurai Principle" applies: return victorious, or not at all.
>
>I have a rule: don't make me guess. It's a simple rule. One
>consequence
>of the rule is that when I create an object using your (anyone's)
>constructor, I expect that object to be able to respond to anything I
>throw at it. If not, you shouldn't have let me create it.
>
>Notice that JavaBeans automatically fail on this rule. I have always
>said that they are evil.
>
>As for using some kind of invariant assertion on the object, like an
>"isValid", your unit tests should perhaps try to uncover any
>place where
>you might require your client to program "by accident" -- that
>is, know
>the order in which to send messages to your object. If you
>write a test
>and think, "I can't call method X before I've called method Y," then
>you're programming by accident. In the words of the great Bob Newhart,
>"Stop it!" Either create a new method Z that calls X and Y in
>that order
>and remove X from the public eye or do something else to make it
>impossible (as much as you can) for a client to write code
>that blows up.
>
>JBR.
>
>Chappell, Simon P wrote:
>
>> There is a school of thought that an object's API should never allow
>> it's internal state to be made unstable/invalid/partially-updated. I
>> would vote for doing whatever it takes to ensure that the
>initial state
>> is valid and then use unit tests to ensure that it stays that way.
>>
